title: 040 Socket example - reading a web page using a simple socket
You should get a response that starts with
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
c
, which indicates a normal HTTP response, followed by the rest of the HTTP header, followed by the raw web page in HTML form.

inline_content.Text: You should get a response that starts with
, which indicates a normal HTTP response, followed by the rest of the HTTP header, followed by the raw web page in HTML form.

title: Note the
readFully()
c
method is important to prevent a premature EOF exception. The last line of the web page may be missing a return, to signal the end of line, then
readLine()
c
will complain, so one must read it by hand or use utility methods from
Apache commons-io IOUtils
a
https://github.com/apache/commons-io/blob/2.5/src/main/java/org/apache/commons/io/IOUtils.java

inline_content.Text: method is important to prevent a premature EOF exception. The last line of the web page may be missing a return, to signal the end of line, then

title: This example is meant as a simple demonstration of connecting to an existing resource using a socket, it’s not a practical way of accessing web pages. If you need to access a web page using Java, it’s best to use an existing HTTP client library such as
Apache’s HTTP Client
a
https://hc.apache.org/httpcomponents-client-ga/
or
Google’s HTTP Client
a
https://developers.google.com/api-client-library/java/google-http-java-client/
